actions and defend against parasites.
Courtesy of Prof. Krzysztof Lewandowski.

rophages.
Courtesy of Prof. Krzysztof Lewandowski.
Fig 8.24 Basophil. The cytoplasm is ﬁ lled with 
dark-staining granules, containing histamine, 
myeloperoxidase and other enzymes. On bind-
ing IgE, histamine is released from the basophil.
Courtesy of Prof. Krzysztof Lewandowski.
Fig 8.20 Neutrophils: (a) ‘toxic granulation’ 
seen in infection or pregnancy; (b) normal ap-
pearances; (c) ‘left shift’: immature forms are 
released with few lobes to their nuclei, seen in 
infection; (d) Barr body (arrow, see text).
Courtesy of Prof. Tangün and Dr Körogˇlu.
